[NI26142] Shawnee News Star Sept 30, 2005

Carl Allen Rackley, 61, went to be with is Lord Thursday, Sept. 29.

He was born to Leo J. and Lelvia (Nuckols) Rackley in Shawnee on Nov. 1 6, 1943. He graduated from Shawnee High School in 1961 and served six yea rs in the 95th Army Reserve. On June 26, 1965, he was married to Sherry Ly nn Thurman at Downtown Pentecostal Holiness Church by the Rev. C.C. Atchle y.He retired from Wolverine Tube after 27 years, where he was a producti on supervisor. Prior to Wolverine, he worked as a carpenter with his dad a nd his brother-in-law, Bill Johnson. He was a member and attended Downto wn Pentecostal Holiness Church. He was a die-hard Sooner fan and a seas on ticket holder for many years.He was preceded in death by his parents, L eo J. and Lelvia Rackley; parents-in-law, Melvin and Beulah Thurman; siste r, Anna Rose; brother, Jesse Rackley, and grandson, Collin Ryan Haley.Surv iving are his wife, Sherry, of the home; two daughters and sons-in-law, Di ana Lynn and Greg Young of Shawnee, Renei and Carl Allen of Ada; grandchil dren, Maegan, Erika and Zachary; sister and brother-in-law, Edith and Bi ll Johnson of Shawnee; brothers-in-law and their wives, Ronnie and Vicki T hurman of Wanette, Donnie and Karen Thurman of Shawnee and Bill and Cat hy Rose of Shawnee; sister-in-law, Dixie Rackley of Shawnee, and numero us other relatives and friends.Service will be 2 p.m. Monday at the Downto wn Pentecostal Holiness Church with the Rev. Ron Baldridge officiating. Bu rial will follow at Resthaven Memorial park. Walker Funeral Servi ce is in charge of arrangements.

[DI26208] Killeen Daily Herald - (Mar/15/2005)

LAMPASAS COUNTY ? Services for Dr. Aaron North Longfield, 83, will be at 10:30 a.m. Saturday at School Creek Baptist Church in Lampasas County with the Rev. Jerry Perkins officiating.

Burial will follow at Smith School Creek Cemetery in Lampasas County.

Longfield died March 13, 2005, in San Antonio.

He was born Oct. 31, 1921, the only child of Mary Jane Nuckles and Arthur North Longfield.

After returning from New Mexico with his parents, Longfield lived on a ranch and attended Unity School in Lampasas County for three years. He moved to Washington, D.C., with his mother in 1930.

Longfield graduated in 1941 from the University of North Carolina and from Northwestern University Medical School in 1944.

While interning in St. Louis, he married the former Betty Lou Liggett of Virden, Ill., on April 7, 1945. She preceded him in death on Jan. 22, 1991.

On Oct. 5, 1991, Longfield married the former Marye Belle Hart of Evanston, Ill.

After service in the Army Medical Corps, Longfield completed residency training in internal medicine in Denver, where he accepted a faculty position at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston.

Longfield later joined the Veterans Administration and served at hospitals in Albuquerque, N.M.; Houston, Marlin and Waco, Texas; and New Orleans, La. He held faculty appointments in pulmonary medicine at each location with the local medical school.

In 1985, he retired from his 35-year medical career with the VA to do ranching in Lampasas County.

Survivors include his wife, Marye Belle Longfield of Lampasas County; a son, Dr. Robert N. Longfield of San Antonio; a daughter, Dr. Lynn A. Gerety of Albuquerque, N.M.; seven grandsons; and a great-grandson.

The family will receive visitors from 6 to 8 p.m. Friday at Briggs-Gamel-Wilcox Funeral in Lampasas.

[DI26229] Earl Lane Nuckels, 58, of Denton passed away on Tuesday, April 14, 2009, at his home. He was born August 20, 1950, in Denton to Bee and Mary (McGuire) Nuckels. He is a graduate of Denton High School, University of North Texas Music Education, and Southwestern Baptist Seminary, Masters of Religious Education. He was married to Martha Jean Christian on June 10, 1972, in Denton. He was currently the Minister of Music at Highland Baptist Church and a store manager with General Nutrition Company.

Earl began his music ministry at the age of 18, and served as music minister for Town North Baptist Church of Denton, McKinney Street Baptist Church of Denton, FBC Little Elm, Trinity Baptist Church of Sherman, FBC Henrietta and Highland Baptist Church of Denton. He was a member of the Grand Chorus and Acapella Choir at UNT, the Singing Men of Texas and Outstanding Young Men of America.

A funeral service will be held at 10 a.m. Saturday, April 18, 2009, at Highland Baptist Church, 600 Highland St. in Denton, with Rev. Jimmy Christian and Rev. Eddie Schafer officiating. Burial will follow in the Little Elm Cemetery in Little Elm. The family will be at the Mulkey-Mason, Jack Schmitz and Son Funeral Home, 705 N. Locust St., in Denton for visitation on Friday, April 17, 2009, from 7 to 9 p.m.

Mr. Nuckels is survived by his wife, Martha (Christian) Nuckels; two sons, Christian Nuckels and wife Michaela, and Jordan Nuckels, all of Denton; three brothers, and their wives, George and Rosa Nuckels of San Antonio, Donald and Joyce Nuckels of Stoney, and Thomas and Donna Nuckels of The Colony; many nieces and nephews; and a granddaughter, Emorie Bryton Nuckels.

[DI26272] Ellen Crow Nuckolls, 88, a longtime resident of Georgetown passed away on Friday, April 8, 2011. Visitation will be held on Saturday, April 9, 2011 at The Gabriels Funeral Chapel, 393 North IH 35, Georgetown, Texas. A service celebrating her life and her faith in her Lord will be held on Sunday, April 10, 2011 at 2:00PM at The Gabriels Funeral Chapel, followed by a reception. Interment will follow at IOOF Cemetery.Ellen was born April 28, 1922 in Durant, Mississippi to the late George and Maud Ellis Crow.She was preceded in death by her brother, George Crow and her loving husband of 67 years, Paul Milton Nuckolls, Sr., who passed away on July 28, 2010.Ellen lived in the South most of her life. She was living in Birmingham, Alabama when she met the love of her life, Paul. She attended Wheeler Business College, where she was voted "Most Beautiful" and was the school's representative for a beauty pageant in Birmingham. Paul and Ellen were married on February 28, 1943 in Auburn, Alabama, the same day of Paul's graduation. Shortly thereafter they departed to his first duty station for the Army. Ellen spent the early part of her marriage with Paul serving in the Army during WWII, while she herself contributing to the war effort operating IBM equipment.After Paul returned from the war they lived in Birmingham and Shreveport before eventually settling in Houston, Texas, where they lived for many many years. Ellen supported Paul in all of his business adventures, raising their three children and creating a wonderful home for their family. Ellen was raised in a Christian home and she and Paul created the same life for their children and grandchildren. Both Paul and Ellen loved the Christmas season and made each year a memorable experience for the family. Ellen enjoyed preparing for the holidays with all of the cooking and decorating that entailed. Ellen enjoyed artistic endeavors throughout her life: playing the piano, painting, sewing and creating needle point art pieces. Her family is left with many cherished pieces that she created for them.Paul and Ellen moved to Georgetown in the late eighties. Upon moving to Georgetown, they became members of First Baptist Church of Georgetown where they were members of the Celebration Life Group. Together with their daughter, Nancy, Paul and Ellen owned and operated The Candle Factory here in Georgetown for over 20 years. Ellen used her artistic hand at the Candle Factory by painting many of the luminaries that were produced. Ellen also had a passion for bird watching and growing flowers and was very knowledgeable of different the bird species. In her long life Ellen enjoyed collecting Sabina Glass, Hummel Figurines and many Porcelain birds. Her legacy will live on with her family and friends through the artwork and collectibles she has left for them to cherish.Ellen leaves behind her loving children, Nancy White and her husband Stanley of Georgetown, Paul Nuckolls, Jr. and his wife Donnie of Dallas, and Jan Bauer and her husband Benno of Houston; her grandchildren, Thomas Blom and his wife Pascal, Hans Blom and his wife Ann Kristin, Scott White and his fiancé Heather Mitchell, Michael White and his wife Christina, Josh White and his wife Melissa, Jon Moore and his wife Teresa, Luis Moore, Emily Bauer; great grandchildren, Christopher Blom, Wolfgang Blom, Lise Kristin Blom, Till Simon, Tristan Simon, Taylor Pogue, Amanda White, Austin White, Kate White, Melanie Moore, Nicole Moore and Tyler Moore; her niece, Susan Nuckolls; along numerous other loving family members and friends.The family would like to give a special thanks to Laura Moorhead for her many hours and loving care she gave to Ellen. Also the staff of Sterling House in Georgetown and the Resolution Hospice Nurses and staff for all the care and comfort they provided for Ellen. Ellen's family deeply appreciates all they have done.Memorial contributions in Ellen and Paul Nuckolls name should be sent to eh Texas Baptist Children's Home in Round Rock, Texas. Personal words of comfort may be sent to the family online at www.gabrielsfuneral.com.

[NI26495] Marty was born August 31, 1966, the second born child of James Frank Nuckles and Sally Ruth McDermott Nuckles, at Grand Forks AFB Hospital, North Dakota. He attended Sacred Heart Elementary School, Pearce Jr. High School, and he graduated in 1984 from LBJ High School, Austin, Travis Co., Texas, USA. He attended Austin Community College, Austin, Travis Co., Texas for two years before joining the United States Air Force.

Marty was a charter member of the Knights of Columbus Council 8141 Sacred Heart Catholic church. He was an avid hunter and fisherman. He was employed by Mid America Steel of Fargo, North Dakota, USA.

Marty is survived by his parents, Jim and Sally Nuckles, his brother Michael Nuckles, nieces, Courtney, Megan, Kellie, and numerous Aunts, Uncles, and Cousins. He had many friends in North Dakota and Texas.

When Marty was a child, he spent some time on the farm with his grandparents whom he dearly loved. His grandfather would take him to the country barber at Adamsville, to get his hair cut. The barber was Payne West. Payne West used to kid him and tell him if he did not sit still, he would cut an ear off and put it in the lard can in the corner. He had a collection of ears in which he used for fish bait. Clever Marty, soon changed the barber's name to Wayne Pest.

Marty also had a lot of freckles from his irish ancestry. Friends like to ask him if he got his sun tan through a screen door. His Uncle Reuben aka "Uncle Hunk" used to tell him if he would eat lots of onions his freckles would go away. Well, he soon learned that onions did not remove freckles, but it was a vegetable in which he liked.

Marty will be missed by all the people who knew him.

Much love to Marty,from your "Aunt Polly"

[DI26648] Florine "Nanny" Nuckols McKinny, 95, of Bloomington passed away Friday, March 16, 2012. She was born March 12, 1917, in Grapeland to the late William and Ida Brown Garrard. She was a homemaker and a member of the Methodist church.Survivors include her daughters, Peggy Chamrad of Placedo, and Linda (Allen) Martin of Baytown; son, Dale (Sherry) Nuckols of Waco; brother, Pack Garrard of Shreveport, Louisiana; step-son, Wayne McKinny of California; 8 grandchildren, Keith, Kevin and Kirk Autry, Tracy Martin, Misty Williams, Dustin Martin, Julie Morriss and Derek Nuckols; 9 step grandchildren; 12 great-grandchildren, 14 step great-grandchildren; 5 great great-grandchildren.In addition to her parents she was preceded in death by her first husband, Forrest Nuckols; her second husband, W. L. McKinny; step daughter, Willie Pearl Fowler; step sons, Stanley and Preston McKinny.The family will receive friends from 7 \endash 8 pm Monday, March 19, 2012, at Rosewood Funeral Chapels.Funeral services will be held at 10 am Tuesday, March 20, 2012, at Bloomington United Methodist Church, Revs. Bill Walles and Mike Swearingen officiating. Burial will follow at Crescent Valley Cemetery.Pallbearers will be Keith Autry, Kevin Autry, Kirk Autry, Dustin Martin, Jimmy Williams and Michael Autry.Memorials may be made to the Bloomington United Methodist Church.Words of comfort may be shared with the family at www.rosewoodfuneralchapel.com.

[DI26654] Andrew William "Bill" McCarley Jr., born on Jan. 27, 1944, went home to be with his Lord Jesus on Sunday, Aug. 24, 2008.

Bill was born in Roscoe to A.W. and Joyce (Nuckols) McCarley and was raised in and graduated from high school in Sweetwater. Bill was preceded in death by both his mother and father and his beloved son, J.W.Bill worked for Mobil Oil Corporation and later worked for the United States Postal Service in Midland. He met and married Judy Swails in 1997. They resided in Midland for eight years before moving to Fort Worth to be near their grandchildren.

Leaving to cherish his memory is his wife, Judy of Fort Worth; his sons, Timothy McCarley of Midland and Mark McCarley of Texarkana; his stepdaughter and son-in-law, Amber and Shane Rowland of Fort Worth; and two grandchildren, Lexie and Caden.Both of these babies will miss their Paw Paw but Lexie will especially miss playing checkers with him because most of the time he let her win.Also leaving to cherish his memory is his big brother, Larry McCarley and his wife, Judy, of Waco, and many aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews.He was a former, active member of the 1st Assembly of God Church in Midland before moving to Fort Worth where he loved to play drums on the praise and worship team. He was a more recent member of Turning Point Church in Fort Worth, where he had made many new friends.Bill and Judy loved to open their home to many church functions where everyone enjoyed listening to Bill tell jokes and funny stories. He was blessed by his many friends and they will miss him.The family will receive guests from 6-8 p.m. Tuesday, Aug. 26, 2008, in the Thomas Funeral Home in Midland.A celebration of his life will be held at 1 p.m. Wednesday, Aug. 27, 2008, in the 1st Assembly of God Church in Midland with Pastor Mike Hanks officiating. Graveside services will be held in the Sweetwater Cemetery.Pallbearers will be Loal Phipps, Mike Hughes, Paul Morris, Randy Vickers, Royce Lane and Chris Baugh.Honorary pallbearers will be James Tompkins, Bert Robinson, David Day, Rick Odom, Waylon Wood, Michael Hughes, Frank Melgoza, Jesse Lujan and Ricky Reyes.The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Andrew W. McCarley Memorial Fund at and Bank of American or his benevolence fund at 1st Assembly of God Church, 100 W. Wadley, Midland, TX.From THE SWEETWATER (TX) REPORTER (8/26/2008)

[DI26694] Kerry Celise Pace, 55, went to her final home to be with her lord on Friday, March 23, 2012, in Alamogordo, after a long battle with an unknown type of dystrophy.

She was born Sept. 9, 1956 in Abilene, Texas, to Berylon Darrell and Shirley Mae (Nuckols) Pace.

She was a member of Bethel Baptist Church.

She is survived by her parents, B. Darrell and Shirley M. Pace; her brother Berry Dale Pace and wife, Marjo; nieces Rachele Cabezuela and husband, Jessie, and their children Christopher and Tyler; Britney Pace, Maaike Long and her children Austyn and Makenzie; nephew Roy Thomas and wife, Misty, and their children Tristin and Haley; her caregiver and best friend, Lupe Sanchez; numerous aunts, uncles, cousins and a host of friends.

Funeral services will be 2 p.m. Monday, March 26, 2012, at Hamilton-O'Dell Funeral Home with the Rev. Bart Montgomery officiating.

Interment will follow at Monte Vista Cemetery.

The family will greet friends from 2-4 p.m. Sunday, March 25, 2012, at Hamilton-O'Dell Funeral Home, 1334 N. Scenic Drive, in Alamogordo.

In lieu of flowers, contributions on Kerry's behalf may be made to the National Muscular Dystrophy Association at: Muscular Dystrophy Association National Headquarters, 3300 E. Sunrise Drive, Tucson, AZ 85718

To sign the online register book, please visit www.hamiltonodell.com.

[NI26746] Biography of Virgil Port Nuckols by A F Oates, sent to NWK 11/2007 by

tnuckols@austin.rr.com

Virgil Port Nuckols

Virgil was born to Pouncy Nuckols and Tinnie C McCay on the 18 of Ootober 1881 in Johnson Co, Texas. His mother passed away when Virgil was a small boy, and he and his brother Daniel, were raised by their grandparents, William Boling McCay and Arena Catherine Bell. Virgil remained with his grandparents for the most of his teenage life. When he was twenty two years of age, he and the lady of his choice, Miss Mornie Louisa Tidwell, we reunited in marriage on Nov 1, 1903 at Midlothan Texas. To this union were born three children, a girl Ruby, and two boys, Rena Jarrell, better known as Texas Kidd Jr and Grafton Nickum, better known as Texas Kidd. Virgil and his wife were born to be rodeo performers. Virgil was among the best hands in his day and the event that he excelled in was the saddle bronc riding contest. Virgil and Lou also taught their children to perform in all events, such as saddle bronc riding, bull riding, bareback bronc riding, and others. They taught them well and they were among the "tophands" of the western range. Texas Kidd Jr was among the best in saddle bronc riding and in his early career, he also rode bulls. On two occasions, 1940 and 1943, Texas Kidd Jr west as a performer and a participant to Madison quare Gardens World's Championship Rodeo in New York City. It was in the saddle bronc riding contest on the 13 of Oct 1940 that Texas Kidd Jr came out on that onery critter known as "Jackson" to delight and amuse the crowd at the Garden. Jr. competed against tophands from the Rio Grande to the Canadian border. To mention a few of the places, Dallas Texas, Denver, Colorado, Nevada, Montana, Fort Worth, Texas, and Cheyenne Wyoming. In the exhibitor shows, Ruby Nuckols was a performer in the cowgirls' bull riding, saddle bronc riding, and bareback riding events. It was the bull riding events that she gave the crowd a thrill. She would come out of the chute astride a bull, but, much to the delight of the fans, she would be facing backward instead of forward. Ruby states in her memoirs that it was easier to ride facing backwards because she could lock her legs around the bull's neck. Grafton, better known as Texas Kidd, has ridden more than his share of broncos. The events that he preferred were saddle bronc, bareback bronc, and bull riding. On the mantel over the fireplace in his home you will see some of the many trophies that he has won over the years. Among them is the Saddle Bronc Riding Championship Trophy, won at Carlsbad, New Mexico, in 1936. In the fron room hangs a huge picture of Grafton, peacefully mounted astride a beautiful paint. Many motion pictures of Texas Kidd taken while he was performing in rodeos throughout the west are to be found in his home. They, as well as the trophies, have been preserved by his wife, Irene Agnes Wallis, after the retirement of Virgil Nuckols, Grafton operated the Texas Kidd shows fron 1942 to 1947. It w as R.C.A. approved and they toured the entire states of Texas, Oklahoma and Louisianna.

For many years, Floy Estus Brazzell performed with the Texas Kidd Shows. She thrilled the spectators with her skillful rides in the saddle bronc and bull riding events. She was a quaret Cherikee Indian and a tophand, with or without the saddle. Virgil and Lou taught the in-laws the tricks of the trade and practically all the family participated in the show owned by Virgil and Lou and known as Texas Kidd Wild West Shows. They showed in many of the states, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Louisianna, Arkansas, Michigan, Kansas, Missouri, Illinois,

Des Moines Iowa, Minneapolis, Minnesota and the length and breadth of Texas. Virgil Port Nuckols departed this life on the 20th of May 1946 on the same day a rodeo opened at Fort Worth Texas. Virgil's horse was saddled, and as he stood at attention in the center of the ring, the band played "Empty Saddles" in tribute to a champion who had gone on to the "Great Round-up".

[DI26746] Fort Worth Star Telegram June 1945

Virgil Nuckols, Pioneer Rodeo Producer Dies

Vrigil (Texas Kidd) Nuckols, 67, pioneer owner and producer of wild west r odeos, died at 3 p.m. Thursday at his residence after an illness of nine weeks. Mr Nuckols early in life became known around his native Grandview for his daring ability to ride the wildest horses and catle on his father 's farm. Young Virgil later became a professional bronc rider and won t op prize money at rodeos over the country. He later organized his own traveling roedo and added a carnival which played in 27 states. At one time there were more than 500 persons in the troupe. He is credited with giving m any now famous rodeo contestants their final chance. Thransportation difficulties during the war forced him to retire in 1942. He had operated a used car lot at 110 S Main ST since that time. Survivors are his widow, two sons, Grafton N and J Reno (Texas Kidd Jr) Nuckols, both well-known ro deo contestants her; a daughter Mrs Ruby Wooldridge, Burleson; five brothe rs, Dan and Marvin of California, Jack and Joe of Abilene, and Bert Nucko ls of Pampa; two sisters, Mrs Beulah Riddling, Hobart, Okla and Mrs Mary M urphy, Austin and four grandchildren. Funeral services will be conduct ed at 2 p.m. Sunday in Harris Funeral Home. Burial will be at Oak Grove Cemetery near Burleson.

[DI26780] Isabelle Nuckolls, the daughter of S Elias and Clara (Thompson) Moats, was born November 29, 1917 in Grundy County, Iowa and passed away surrounded by her family on March 24, 2014 at the Greene County Long Term Care Facility in Jefferson, Iowa. She lived a full life to the age of 96 years, 3 months and 25 days.

Isabelle attended and graduated from the Conrad High School in 1935 and later attended the Marshalltown Business College; graduating in 1937. After college, Isabelle worked for the Marshall County Engineer's office where she met Denver Nuckolls. On November 10, 1940, Dorothy Isabelle Moats was united in marriage to Denver L. Nuckolls at her parent's home in Grundy County, Iowa. Three daughters were born to this union; Janine Birch of Paton, Janet Sabus of Jefferson and Jennifer (Mrs. Chuck Hoyt) of Creston. After their marriage, the couple made their home in Paton where Denver managed the Paton office of the Home State Bank. During the time Denver was serving in WWII, Isabelle served as manager of the bank from 1942 to 1945. Upon Denver's discharge from the service, he returned to the bank and in 1951, the family moved to Stratford. They returned to Paton in 1963 and Denver served as President of the Community State Bank until his death in 1986. Isabelle worked at the bank from 1970 and became President of the bank in 1986 following Denver's death.

Isabelle was a member of the Salem United Methodist Church in Paton and of the U.M.W. She was also a member of the American Legion Auxiliary, and Greene County Historical Society and a past member of Order of Eastern Star and Greene County Arts Council. Isabelle received the Governor's Volunteer Award in 1995, being nominated by the Paton-Churdan School. As an active member of the American Legion Auxiliary, Isabelle was instrumental in developing the "Avenue of Flags" in the Paton Township Cemetery. She was also bestowed a "Friends of 4-H" Award. Never wanting accolades for her generosity, she always gave wherever there was a need in Paton, Greene County and all of the surrounding area.

Isabelle is survived by her three daughters, five grandchildren; Jennifer (Korey) Hoskins of Ogden, Brian (Jana) Happe of Cherokee, Mike (Nikki) Happe of Jefferson, Aaron (Lindsay) Hoyt of Hoboken, N.J. and Ryan (Jennifer) Hoyt of Creston and twelve great-grandchildren; Tyler Happe, Kody, Kacie, Denver & Quintin Hoskins, Jaylee and Colton Happe, Jaislynn Baugh, Mason, Elyssa, & Wilson Happe and Cameron Hoyt, a sister-in-law, Betty Phillips and many nephews and nieces. She was preceded in death by her parents, husband, two brothers; Edgar and Glen Moats, a sister, Cecel Ferguson and son-in-law, David Birch.

A celebration of Isabelle's life was held Monday, March 31, 2014, at 10:30 A.M. from the Salem United Methodist Church in Paton, Iowa with Rev David Arulnathan officiating. Musical selections at the service were "How Great Thou Art" sung by the congregation and accompanied by organist, Janice Tilley and "He Touched Me" and "Fill My Cup, Lord" sung by soloist, Doyle Carlson and accompanied by pianist, Danille Curtis. Burial was made at the Paton Township Cemetery.

Serving as casket bearers were Jennifer Hoskins, Brian Happe, Mike Happe, Aaron Hoyt, Ryan Hoyt and Tyler Happe. Honorary bearers were Community State Bank Directors and employees.

[NI26786] Odessa - Randy D. Nuckols was born March 22, 1977, to Don and Pam Nuckols in Slidell, LA. At the young age of 30, he left this life on Friday, May 18, 2007, in Midland, TX. As a boy, Randy hated to see anyone go hungry and would often leave food for the homeless under the bridges where they slept and leave before they could thank him. He graduated from Permian High School in 1995. Later that year he married his junior high sweetheart and the love of his life, Angie Gibson on November 11 in Las Vegas, Nevada. Randy's second love was his daughter, Emily, who brought even more added joy to his life. He loved to have tea parties with her and often fell asleep watching cartoons with her at night. Some of the other things Randy enjoyed were riding his Harley, drag racing, riding Motocross bikes and four-wheelers. He liked watching football, playing his PS2 and watching movies. He was especially intrigued by the History and Military Channel. Randy loved the outdoors; barbecuing and spending time with his family were some of his greatest joys. Randy was involved in many aspects of law enforcement. He worked as a prison guard for the TDCJ, a police officer in Lamesa, and as a deputy sheriff in Midland for many years. Recently, Randy started a new phase in his life as a salesman for Weatherford. He is survived by his loving wife, Angie Nuckols and their beautiful daughter, Emily Nuckols, both of Midland; his mother, Pam Nuckols of Odessa; and father, Don Nuckols and wife Kristie, also of Odessa. His Grandpa and Grandma, Jim and Melba Paysinger of Odessa, and great-grandmother, Nann ie of Pine Bluff, Arkansas; one half- brother, Greg Nuckols of Abilene, TX; and one half-sister, Tabitha Hughes and her husband Will, their childre n, Brian and Brittany, all of Little Rock, Arkansas, survive him. One uncle, Desmond Stanford and his wife, Sheila of Ft. Walton Beach, Florida survive him. Also surviving him are his cousins, Chrissy and Jennifer Stanford, and his Aunt, Judy Stanford of Dallas, TX, and his great-uncle, Jerry Ritchey of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. He was preceded in death by his uncle, Mike Stanford. Visitation will be held from 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. Tuesda y, May 22, 2007, at Hubbard-Kelly Funeral Home. On Wednesday, May 23, 20 07 at 2:00 p.m. at Hubbard-Kelly Chapel with the Rev. Jimmy Braswell offic iating, his life will be celebrated as he lived it, laid back and casua l. He will be laid to rest at Sunset Memorial Gardens. Pallbearers wi ll be best friend, Brent Miller, Joey Lewallen, Robert Floyd, Richard Hai n, Tommy Ward and Greg Nuckols. Please dress casual for the service. Servi ces entrusted to Hubbard-Kelly Funeral Home.
